_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM



The Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule requires facilities to develop and/or resubmit a plan every 5 years (or sooner) depending on accident history, corrections to emergency contact information, changes to processes and/or other required elements.  The rule requires facilities to provide an executive summary of the following information:



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Lewisport Rolling Mill (LRM) has developed and implemented a process safety management (PSM) plan as part of their accidental release/emergency response program.  These programs involve a range of senior management personnel, including the senior plant management, Health, Safety, and Environmental (HSE) manager and staff, maintenance, production, and other ancillary employees.  Additionally, LRM conducts regular safety meetings and training involving many levels of personnel.  LRM's policies and procedures are outlined in the respective plans. It is LRM's policy to inspect, maintain and operate equipment and facilities in a manner to prevent accidents, including release of hazardous materials; and to train employees in prevention, as well as to prepare them to respond rapidly and effectively should an accident occur.



Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances Handled

The facility uses chlorine in the aluminum purification process.  Chlorine is stored in liquid form under pressure in one-ton containers.  Chlorine gas from the containers is piped to the aluminum melting furnaces where it is injected in molten aluminum to remove impurities.  



There are two separate systems that utilize chlorine:  The South chlorine system and the North chlorine system.  However, only the South chlorine system inventory exceeds the RMP threshold for chlorine of 2,500 pounds in a single process. The maximum intended inventory is 16,000 pounds (8 full one-ton containers) in the South chlorine building at one time.  Th

is does not include the chlorine in the piping from the storage building to the melters in South casting.



General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The facility maintains a Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals plan prepared in accordance with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) regulation 29 CFR 1910.119.  LRM also utilizes a preventative maintenance program for its system components.  As part of this program, maintenance personnel inspect the chlorine systems' operating parameters and monitoring system according to the PSM Mechanical Integrity program preventative maintenance (PM) schedule.  



Five-year Accident History

There have been 2 onsite accidents involving chlorine that resulted in greater than first aid treatment to individual employees.  There have been no additional accidents involving chlorine at this facility that have resulted in death(s), injuries, property damage, evacuations, environmental damage or sheltering in place.



Emergency Response Program

LRM has implemented an Emergency Response Plan in accordance with the OSHA PSM regulations.  The facility has a trained emergency response team that will respond in the event of a hazardous material release, fire or other emergency situation.  The Emergency Response Plan contains specific information regarding Emergency Response organization and procedures (including chlorine release scenarios), as well as incident notification, mitigation, and incident preparedness.  In addition, LRM training program includes annual refreshers.  The facility has also developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to address other emergency response related incidents such as bomb threats, spills or releases of hazardous materials, evacuation, and tornados or dangerous weather conditions.
